subject: Re: Starting out as well...
msgSnippet: I once had your doubts as well The Read alphabet is very easy to learn, the only thing needed to master it in a short time is practice. Also, it is better to
messageBody:
I once had your doubts as well
The Read alphabet is very easy to learn, the only thing needed
to master it in a short time is practice. Also, it is better to
write it out than to type it.
In the second stage of Quickscript 70% of all the words you
write are either standardized or abbreviated. Most of the other
words ,like speech, can be recognized easely.
The best source on the Read Alphabet is of course the manual
avaliable in this group's files section. Print it, if you can, for
easy reference.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, M. V. Domínguez Espinosa
<guelguez@...> wrote:
>
> I've been following the activities of this group, which has been
quite
> prolific, for the past couple of years, but I've yet to take the
time
> to actually learn the Read Alphabet. I am just about to take this
on,
> and I'm in the process of trying out fonts for my Mac -- so please
> excuse in advance my ignorance about this alphabet...
>
> Anyway, much like Rachel in a related posting, over the years I've
> used shorthand-like scripts that I've invented myself for my own
use.
> One thing that I discovered in the process is that English spelling
> (or the attitude towards it) permits much variation, be it
regional or
> temporal, in pronunciation.
>
> I'm wondering if this has been discussed in this forum? How does
> Quikscript allow for the ever-changing pronunciation of English as
it
> evolves over time (and across borders)? Is the spelling of words
> changed merely based upon who is saying them?
>
> Also, about shapes of the glyphs themselves, they don't appear to
flow
> nicely from one to the next. I'm wondering why some "natural"
> alphabet, such as Arabic, has not been retrofitted to English if a
> quick and flowing way to write is the intended goal?
>
> regards,
> Michael
>
